<u>The Malpighian tubules <\u>.
Many conflicting statements have been made concern-
ing the nitrogenous and other compounds said to be 
present or absent in the fluid of the Malpighian 
tubules of the <u>Insecta<\u> and <u>Arachnida <\u>. Plateau +
states, for example, that he could not find uric 
acid or urates in the Malpighian tubules of 
spiders. Now, as a matter of fact, Mr. A. Johnstone,
[F.?]G.S. (Demonstrator in Geology in the University of 
Edinburgh), and the author++ have extracted sodium 
[u?]rate from the Malpighian tubules of <u>Tegenaria 
domestica<\u>, as well from those of other <u>Arachnida <\u>;
and this organic salt may always be detected in the 
secretion of these animals when the proper tests are 
skilfully applied.
Plateau, <u> Bull. de l’Acad. de Belgique <\u>, 1878; <u>Bull. de la Societe 
Belge de Microscopie <\u>, 1878.
Griffiths and Johnstone, <u>Proc. Roy. Soc. Edinb<\u>., vol.15, p.111.
